title-group.article-title: Recovery of nickel from spent NiO/Al2O3 catalyst through sulfuric acid leaching, precipitation and solvent extraction

contrib-group.aff: School of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: F Rashchi, School of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, P.O. Box 11155-4563, Tehran, Iran Email: rashchi@ut.ac.ir

abstract.p: Effective recovery of nickel (Ni) from spent NiO/Al2O3 catalyst in a simple hydrometallurgical route is suggested. Nickel recovery of 99.5% was achieved with sulfuric acid leaching. The leach liquor was partly neutralized and nickel ammonium sulfate was precipitated by adding ammonia. The nickel in the supernatant was concentrated by solvent extraction using D2EHPA and subsequently stripped back into sulfuric acid and returned to the precipitation stage. Necessary counter current extraction and stripping stages were determined in McCabe–Thiele diagrams. The suggested method appears simple and very effective in recovering nickel from spent catalysts from the petrochemical industry

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The petrochemical industry is the major consumer of various types of catalyst in several processes. As reported by Rapaport (2000) all spent hydro-processing catalysts are classified as hazardous waste by the US Environmental Protection Agency.

In light of the decreasing availability of high-grade natural resources for many costly metals, energy considerations and economic aspects, the recovery of valuable metals from spent catalyst has received special attention. Extensive studies have been performed in recent years to find possible treatments for these waste materials. Furimsky (1996), Clifford (1997) and Marafi and Stanislaus (2008a, b) have reviewed the various options for safe disposal and treatment of spent catalysts. Marafi and Stanislaus (2008a) reviewed some of the commercial processes of spent catalyst recycling. Mulak et al. (2005) studied the kinetics of nickel leaching from spent catalysts, Al-Mansi and Abdel Monem (2002) investigated the leaching process as well as the nickel recovery from the leach liquor, as nickel sulfate, by evaporation and reported a 99% recovery, Abdel-Al and Rashed (2004) only studied the leaching parameters and the kinetic aspects of the Ni leaching and Sahu et al. (2005) reported the effect of persulfate-based additives on shortening the leaching time.

Previous studies have focused mainly on the leaching step. However, one of the most important steps in recovering the metals is the hydrometallurgical processing of leach liquors. This step is mainly involving processes such as selective precipitation, ion exchange, carbon adsorption, solvent extraction, electrolysis, etc. These methods have been widely used in processing of nickel-containing solutions (Lee et al., 2010; Moskalyk and Alfantazi, 2002).

In this study, a simple and effective hydrometallurgical process for recovery of nickel from spent NiO/Al2O3 catalyst was developed, including sulfuric acid leaching, precipitation of nickel as nickel ammonium sulfate and concentration of precipitation effluent by solvent extraction using D2EHPA. sec.title: Materials and characterization
sec.p: Sulfuric acid (98%), murexide, ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) and ammonia solution (25%) were obtained from Merck, Germany, di-(2-ethylhexyl) phosphoric acid (D2EHPA) was obtained from Bayer, Germany and kerosene was purchased from Tehran Oil Refinery.

Spent nickel oxide catalyst used in this study was obtained from the refining unit of Kharg Petrochemical Complex, Iran. The spent catalyst was roasted in a muffle furnace at 500°C for 5 h to remove coke, sulfur and oil, then it was ground and sieved. A particle size range of 1 to 2.36 mm (−8 + 18 mesh) was selected for the leaching experiments. The chemical analysis shown in Table 1 was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2100 atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Philips PW 1730, Co-Kα. The XRD analysis indicated that the major structural phases in the spent catalyst were α-alumina (α-Al2O3), nickel oxide (NiO) and nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4).

caption.p: Chemical analysis of the spent catalyst

sec.title: Leaching
sec.p: All leaching experiments were performed in a condenser-equipped four-neck flask immersed in a water bath, for temperature control at ± 1°C tolerance; placed on a magnetic stirrer. In a typical leaching test, 30 g of spent catalyst was mixed with 300 mL sulfuric acid solution at the specified concentration. The mixture was agitated at a constant rate of 700 rpm and specified temperature. At selected time intervals 2 mL of the slurry was taken out by pipette and filtered immediately and the filtrate used for nickel analysis. The solids were discarded and thus the solid/liquid ratio (S/L) in the reactor was maintained almost constant at 0.1 gm L−1. The nickel content was determined by complexometric titration using EDTA and murexide as indicator according to Vogel (1989).

sec.title: Precipitation
sec.p: In this stage, Ni was precipitated from the leach liquor. An adequate amount of aqueous ammonia (NH3, 25%) was added drop-wise under slow stirring (200 rpm) at room temperature (25 ± 2°C). In the pH range 1–5 a maximum precipitation of approximately 90% was achieved. The recoverable precipitate was filtered off the solution.

sec.title: Solvent extraction
sec.p: The Ni removal from the filtrate was carried out by solvent extraction using D2EHPA in kerosene at varying concentrations, 5, 10, 15 and 20% (w/v). The initial filtrate contained 1.2 g L−1 of Ni. All batch solvent extraction experiments were performed at room temperature (25 ± 2°C) in a 500 mL beaker, which was submerged in a water bath equipped with a mechanical stirrer, a thermometer and a pH electrode. The two phases were contacted by rapid stirring and pH was controlled by adding ammonia during the process. The mixture was stirred for 5 min to reach the equilibrium condition. Then the two phases were allowed to separate using a decanter-separating funnel. The resulting Ni concentration in the aqueous phase was determined by titration. The amount and thus concentration of Ni in the organic phase was calculated as the difference between the analysed Ni concentrations in the aqueous phase before and after extraction by mass balance.

Stripping of Ni from the loaded organic phase was carried out with 1 mol L−1 sulfuric acid solution at room temperature (25 ± 2°C). The concentrated aqueous acid solution of Ni obtained was returned to the precipitation step (Figure 1).

sec.title: Leaching
sec.p: At the beginning of the leaching process, the best condition for acid concentration, temperature, S/L and stirring speed were determined through some preliminary experiments. Only results for the first two parameters are presented below.

Figure 2 illustrates the effect of varying initial H2SO4 concentration from 1 to 4 mol L−1 on the leaching of Ni for S/L = 0.1 g mL−1 at 85°C and 700 rpm. It shows that more than 99% of nickel was extracted from the spent catalyst at all the sulfuric acid concentrations. Increasing the concentration of sulfuric acid enhanced the efficiency and reduced the time of the leaching process.

caption.p: Effect of H2SO4 concentration on nickel extraction leaching (temperature: 85°C; S/L = 0.1 g mL−1; particle size: 1–2.36 mm, stirring speed: 700 rpm).

sec.p: Figure 3 illustrates the effect of temperature on the percentage of Ni leached from the spent catalyst at 70, 75, 80 and 85°C. Using 4 mol L−1 H2SO4, S/L = 0.1 g mL−1 and 700 rpm. According to this figure, the Ni leaching rate increased as the temperature rose from 70 to 85°C and that above 80°C approximately 99% Ni leaching can be obtained in less than 30 min.

caption.p: Effect of temperature on nickel extraction leaching (H2SO4: 4 mol L−1; S/L = 0.1 g mL−1; particle size: 1–2.36 mm, stirring speed: 700 rpm).

sec.title: Leach liquor processing
sec.p: Leach liquor Ni concentrations were approximately 12.1 g L−1. The initial recovery of nickel from this solution was performed through precipitation by adding aqueous ammonia producing a greenish precipitate of Ni. According to the XRD analysis, the precipitate was pure nickel ammonium sulfate hexahydrate crystals, which is widely used in the Ni plating industry. sec.p: The McCabe–Thiele diagram was constructed for this reaction (7) and the theoretical number of required counter-current extraction stages was estimated. This diagram was constructed by contacting the aqueous feed solution containing 1.2 g L−1 nickel with a fixed 10% D2EHPA concentration in kerosene and varying the A/O phase ratios from 1 to 7 at 25 ± 2°C. Figure 6 illustrates the McCabe–Thiele diagram for D2EHPA at pH = 6. Choosing a phase ratio of A/O = 2.5, the diagram indicates that only two stages are required for near zero nickel extraction with D2EHPA.

sec.title: Ni2+ stripping
sec.p: A McCabe–Thiele diagram was also constructed for Ni2+ stripping from the loaded organic phase with 2.7 g L−1 Ni with 1 mol L−1 sulfuric acid at phase ratios (O/A) of 1 to 7 at 25 ± 2°C. According to the diagram, only one stage is required for complete nickel stripping from loaded D2EHPA with 1 mol L−1 sulfuric acid.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An environmentally friendly flowsheet with a rather simple combination of processes for recovery of Ni from spent catalysts with near zero Ni released by the effluent is proposed.
An overall recovery of 99.5% of nickel from spent catalyst is possible.
Leaching of 99.5% Ni in the catalyst was achieved using sulfuric acid at 4 mol L−1, t = 85°C and a solid/liquid ratio = 0.1 g mL−1.

Precipitation of 90% Ni from the leach solution was obtained after adding ammonia. Nearly all of the remaining Ni in solution in the filtrate was removed by solvent extraction using D2EHPA followed by stripping into dilute sulfuric acid, and returned to the precipitation stage.
The final product is nickel ammonium sulfate that is widely used in Ni plating industry.
The theoretical stages in a counter current processing for the solvent extraction was two, and in the stripping processes only one stage is necessary.
